text: I'm going to try to do something I've
never done before
keep my foot down take my eyes off the
road and try and crash this car oh that
was close
but it didn't even touch the brake and
that's because it was under safe
conditions on this test track the car in
front was actually an inflatable the one
I was driving uses autonomous emergency
braking or a EB Technology a B uses
sensors fitted this vehicle either
lasers or a camera on this vehicle or
even a radar here in the front and if
there's a potential crash it will warn
the driver if the driver doesn't respond
it will automatically break for the
driver to mitigate or even avoid the
crash completely critics say with prices
ranging from several hundred to several
thousand pounds the system is too
expensive and worried it could lead to
motorists relying too much on technology
but despite the government saying there
are currently no plans to make it
compulsory researchers are already
focused on the next stage of
developments making it possible to avoid
not just cars but people - Dan Whitworth
BBC news
